Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CI-ADDO-EN: Research Repository for Model-Driven Software Development (REMODD)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Model-Driven Development (MDD) is an approach to software development that is gaining traction world-wide. The Repository for Model-Driven Development (ReMoDD) is a resource that has been developed to facilitate and accelerate research and education in MDD through the sharing of high quality modeling experiences. ReMoDD provides facilities for curating, querying, and operating on models. The first version was developed under a prior NSF grant and currently supports a broad and growing community of Software Engineering researchers, practitioners, educators, and students. New requirements emerging from the community of developers and users are the basis for this new grant. The project will significantly improve ReMoDD as follows: (1) To help attract more artifacts from industry, we will provide facilities that can be used to sanitize models so that valuable proprietary information is obfuscated; (2) to help attract artifacts that demonstrate the application of MDD methods on industrial software development problems, we will provide facilities for industry/academia collaborations on industry-relevant challenge problems; (3) to extend the scope of relevant artifacts that can be accessed via ReMoDD, we will work with developers of related repositories (e.g., the European Open Models Initiative) so that searches in ReMoDD will yield artifacts stored in collaborating repositories; and (4) we will extend ReMoDD with social networking features that support, for example, crowd sourcing challenging modeling problems. The enhancement of ReMoDD will be a collaborative effort involving teams from Colorado State University (CSU) and Michigan State University (MSU). ReMoDD has an Advisory Board of leading MDD researchers and industry representatives that are committed to ensuring that ReMoDD continues to be a useful and sustainable community resource.

By providing ReMoDD as MDD community infrastructure, groups performing MDD research will advance the overarching objective of Model Driven software Development (MDD), which is to reduce the cost and effort of developing complex software systems through the use of software models. The problems tackled by MDD researchers are challenging and good solutions typically evolve through a community process driven by feedback from the use of solutions in research and industrial settings. The project will strengthen engagement with the international research community, who will contribute new ideas, share tools, and share in the project effort. To support the international collaboration, this award is being co-funded by NSF?s Office of International and Integrative Activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Model-Driven software Development (MDD) research focuses on how explicit forms of models can be used to engineer dependable software systems. MDD researchers aim to provide cost-effective solutions that support the use of software models as primary artifacts of development. The Repository for Model-Driven Development (ReMoDD) is a resource that was developed to accelerate iterative development of high quality MDD solutions through the sharing of high quality artifacts and modeling experience to support the work of researchers, educators, and practitioners in the modeling community.

Intellectual Merit: Among several research benefits, the ReMoDD website provides artifacts as resources for empirical research in modeling and software engineering; it supports citation of artifacts and enables community-based discussions of specific modeling concerns. Teaching benefits include the use of modeling examples and case studies to illustrate modeling concepts in the classroom or class projects, and having students share models and obtain feedback. ReMoDD allows registered users to manage their personal profile, submit artifacts, search for artifacts, rate and comment on artifacts, manage discussion forums and groups, and create workshop pages. System administrators manage users and submitted artifacts.

ReMoDD also provides a Java-based API that defines the Java interfaces, classes, and exceptions necessary to support the above functionality. We developed an Eclipse plugin that uses the API to connect to ReMoDD from the Eclipse IDE, download artifacts, create new versions inside the IDE, and commit and push the changes back to ReMoDD.

The MDD community has been collecting challenge problems from industrial organizations (in the form of high-level requirements specifications) in various application areas such as autonomous vehicles, sustainability, and user experience modeling. ReMoDD supports such research initiatives. Topics that are extremely relevant in the area of MDD include language engineering, domain-specific languages, model transformations, product lines, validation and verification, and coevolution and collaboration using modeling infrastructure. All of these areas require the MDD community to converge on promising solutions and standards for languages, frameworks, and processes. ReMoDD can  both shape standards as well as promote the use of standards, such as those defined by the Object Management Group.

Broader Impacts: ReMoDD is used worldwide. The total number of registered users is 392. Visits to the ReMoDD website are both from registered and unregistered users (over 2,300 unique pageviews in 2018). The artifacts published in ReMoDD were submitted by academics, industry, groups solving challenge problems, research projects, workshops and focus groups. The artifacts are of various types (e.g., assessment, case study, lecture material, metamodels, methodologies, model transformations, requirements, patterns, and tools). They use a variety of languages (e.g., BPMN, Ecore, feature model, formal specification languages like OCL, UML, URN, Petri nets and Simulink). Distributed community interactions occurred as a result of ReMoDD, such as the CMA workshop series and the Bellairs Modeling Group, where participants from the USA, Canada, the UK, France, Norway, the Netherlands, Portugal, and Luxembourg came together. ReMoDD has also supported workshops (e.g., MiSE@ICSE 2012, AMINO 2013 and 2014) and the MODELS (2017-2019) conference by storing artifacts used in MODELS papers.

As ReMoDD research results are transferred to software engineering curricula, a new generation of software developers will emerge who can develop technologies to build dependable software systems that serve critical societal functions. Society as a whole benefits when critical systems (e.g., autonomous vehicles) operate in a safe and reliable manner.
